title: 115_s830
content: The Act titled "Treat and Reduce Obesity Act of 2017" is cited as the short title. Congress finds that obesity is prevalent among adults aged 65 and over, with 34% affected, leading to increased risks of chronic diseases such as high blood pressure, heart disease, cancer, and diabetes. Medicare beneficiaries with obesity often have multiple chronic conditions, leading to increased healthcare spending. Obesity also reduces life expectancy for both men and women at age 65. The prevalence of obesity among older individuals in the United States is increasing, with a projected half of the elderly population having obesity by 2030. The direct and indirect costs of obesity exceed $450 billion annually, with Medicare beneficiaries with obesity costing $1,964 more than normal-weight beneficiaries. Life expectancy is reduced by 1.6 years for men and 1.4 years for women due to obesity. SEC. 3. Authority to expand health care providers qualified to furnish intensive behavioral therapy. The Social Security Act is amended to allow coverage of intensive behavioral therapy for obesity by various healthcare providers, including physicians, physician assistants, nurse practitioners, clinical psychologists, and registered dietitians. The Social Security Act allows coverage of intensive behavioral therapy for obesity by approved community-based lifestyle counseling programs. The therapy must be coordinated with a physician or primary care practitioner and can be provided in various settings such as an office, hospital outpatient department, or community-based site. The Social Security Act allows coverage of intensive behavioral therapy for obesity by approved community-based lifestyle counseling programs, coordinated with a physician or primary care practitioner in various settings specified by the Secretary. The coordination includes communication of recommendations or treatment plans to the referring physician. SEC. 4. MEDICARE PART D COVERAGE OF OBESITY MEDICATION. Amends the Social Security Act to include coverage of obesity medication for weight loss management in individuals with related comorbidities. Effective date is 2 years after enactment. SEC. 5. REPORT TO CONGRESS. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must submit a report to Congress every 2 years detailing the implementation of the Act's provisions related to obesity treatment and prevention in adults, along with recommendations for better coordination of relevant programs.
